        </div>
      </section> 
    <section class="section blog-contents"> 
      <div class="pa blog-editor">
        <div class="l-container">
          <div class="be__wrapper">
            <div class="be__contents">
              <div class="be__contents-wrapper">
                <p class="wpml-ls-statics-post_translations wpml-ls">This post is also available in: 
    <span class="wpml-ls-slot-post_translations wpml-ls-item wpml-ls-item-ja wpml-ls-first-item wpml-ls-last-item wpml-ls-item-legacy-post-translations"><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.jp/ra-world-ransomware-group-updates-tool-set/" class="wpml-ls-link"><span class="wpml-ls-native" lang="ja">日本語</span><span class="wpml-ls-display"><span class="wpml-ls-bracket"> (</span>Japanese<span class="wpml-ls-bracket">)</span></span></a></span></p><h2><a id="post-135642-_npomtqqah6fl"></a>Executive Summary</h2>
<p>The ransomware group RA Group, now known as RA World, showed a noticeable uptick in their activity since March 2024. About 37% of all posts on their dark web leak site have appeared since March, suggesting this is an emerging group to watch. This article describes the tactics, techniques and procedures (TTPs) used by RA World.</p>
<p>RA World uses a <a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/cyberpedia/what-is-multi-extortion-ransomware" target="_blank" rel="noopener">multi-extortion</a> scheme, which usually includes exfiltrating sensitive data from its victims prior to encrypting it. The ransomware operators then use the exfiltrated data as leverage, threatening to post it on their website in case victims do not meet their ransom demands.</p>
<p>RA World notably experimented with a “cost per customer” calculation. Below victim entries, they posted comments such as, “This company isn’t willing to pay $0.5 per customer to protect their privacy.”</p>
<p>Analysis of the posts on their leak site shows that RA World mainly impacted organizations in the healthcare industry until recently. The group did not appear to have any particular qualms about attacking organizations in a sensitive sector such as healthcare. Midway through 2024, manufacturing became the sector most impacted by the group. It is possible that the shift came from a desire to attack organizations more likely to be able to pay higher ransoms. However, many ransomware groups are simply opportunistic, and it is also possible the change was incidental.</p>
<p>The U.S. is the country most affected by these attacks, followed by countries in Europe and Southeast Asia.</p>
<p>Palo Alto Networks customers are better protected against the ransomware used by RA World through the following products and services:</p>
<ul>
<li><a href="https://docs-cortex.paloaltonetworks.com/p/XDR" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Cortex XDR</a> and <a href="https://docs-cortex.paloaltonetworks.com/p/XSIAM" target="_blank" rel="noopener">XSIAM</a></li>
<li><a href="https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/cdss" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Cloud-Delivered Security Services</a> for the <a href="https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/ngfw" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Next-Generation Firewall</a> such as <a href="https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/wildfire" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Advanced WildFire</a> and <a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/network-security/advanced-url-filtering" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Advanced URL Filtering</a></li>
</ul>
<p>The Cortex XDR anti-ransomware module includes out-of-the-box protections that prevent adverse behavior from the ransomware samples we tested, without the need for specific detection logic or signatures.</p>
<p>The <a href="https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/prisma/prisma-cloud" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Prisma Cloud</a> Defender should be deployed on cloud-based Windows virtual machines for better protection against the ransomware used by the RA World. <a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/cortex/cortex-xpanse" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Cortex Xpanse</a> is able to provide visibility that can prove valuable for proactive protection.</p>
<p>The <a href="https://start.paloaltonetworks.com/contact-unit42.html" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Unit 42 Incident Response team</a> can also be engaged to help with a compromise or to provide a proactive assessment to lower your risk.</p>
<table style="width: 100%;">
<thead>
<tr>
<td style="width: 35%;"><b>Related Unit 42 Topics</b></td>
<td style="width: 100%;"><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/ransomware/" target="_blank" rel="noopener"><b>Ransomware</b></a>, <strong><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/extortion/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Extortion</a></strong></td>
</tr>
</thead>
</table>
<h2><a id="post-135642-_zbzvga5tvt64"></a>RA World Overview</h2>
<p>Ever since <a href="https://blog.talosintelligence.com/ra-group-ransomware/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Talos</a> first described it in 2023, RA World has been steadily active. Out of the organizations it has publicly claimed to have breached, the largest number were in the manufacturing sector. Figure 1 below details the statistics of different sectors affected by the RA World. The data covers the period from mid-2023 to June 6, 2024.</p>
<figure id="attachment_135646" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-135646" style="width: 900px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-135646" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/07/chart.png" alt="Bar chart showing counts of various industries with &quot;Manufacturing&quot; having the highest count and decreasing to &quot;Agriculture&quot; with the lowest. Industries labeled include Transportation and logistics, Wholesale and Retail, Insurance, Pharma and Life Sciences, Healthcare, Finance, Real Estate, Construction, Media and Entertainment, Government, Nonprofit, and Education." width="900" height="544" srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/07/chart.png 1091w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/07/chart-727x440.png 727w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/07/chart-768x465.png 768w" sizes="(max-width: 900px) 100vw, 900px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-135646" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 1. A bar chart showing the victims of the RA World group by sector, according to posts on the group’s dark web leak site.</figcaption></figure>
<p>According to analysis of leak site data, RA World impacts organizations based in the U.S. the most. The group has also impacted organizations in several countries in Europe, such as Germany and France. In Asia, organizations in Taiwan were impacted. In addition, <a href="https://www.trendmicro.com/en_us/research/24/c/multistage-ra-world-ransomware.html" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Trend Micro</a> reported that the group recently carried out a campaign affecting organizations in South America.</p>
<p>When RA World renamed its gang from RA Group, they also changed their encrypted file extensions to <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">.RAWLD</span>. In addition, they changed the title and content of their ransom note to include their new name, as shown in Figure 2 below.</p>
<figure id="attachment_135648" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-135648" style="width: 900px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-135648" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/07/word-image-821867-135642-2.jpeg" alt="Text from a computer screen displaying a ransom note. The note states that data has been stolen and encrypted, offering instructions for contacting the hacker via a provided Tor address. The note warns that failure to comply will result in the public release of sample data within three days and data will be released in batches in seven days. It includes terms for negotiating and references to additional unhappy victims' lists. The file is titled &quot;Data breach warning.txt - Notepad.&quot; Some of the information is redacted. " width="900" height="717" srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/07/word-image-821867-135642-2.jpeg 956w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/07/word-image-821867-135642-2-552x440.jpeg 552w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/07/word-image-821867-135642-2-878x700.jpeg 878w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/07/word-image-821867-135642-2-768x612.jpeg 768w" sizes="(max-width: 900px) 100vw, 900px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-135648" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 2. RA World's revamped ransom note.</figcaption></figure>
<h2><a id="post-135642-_88u90y2lkbze"></a>Leak Site</h2>
<p>RA World maintains a leak site, where the group uploads portions of the stolen data they exfiltrate from their victims to coerce ransom payments. Their website's design also looks upgraded compared to their old website's simple look that was shown in <a href="https://securityaffairs.com/146248/cyber-crime/new-ra-group.html" target="_blank" rel="noopener">previous research</a> in 2023. Figures 3 and 4 below show the two recent iterations of the leak site’s main page.</p>
<figure id="attachment_135650" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-135650" style="width: 900px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-135650" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/07/word-image-824939-135642-3.jpeg" alt="The image displays a screenshot of a website titled &quot;RA World.&quot; The website has a dark theme with a background image of a dimly lit corridor that gives a high-tech, eerie vibe. At the center of the webpage, there is a large banner with the text &quot;Welcome to RA World&quot; followed by a smaller subtext stating, &quot;War is death's feast. I survived, but my friend didn't.&quot; The top navigation includes tabs such as Home and Victim List. The logo &quot;RAW&quot; in a bold style appears prominently." width="900" height="515" srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/07/word-image-824939-135642-3.jpeg 1200w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/07/word-image-824939-135642-3-770x440.jpeg 770w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/07/word-image-824939-135642-3-768x439.jpeg 768w" sizes="(max-width: 900px) 100vw, 900px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-135650" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 3. RA World’s leak site main page from early 2024.</figcaption></figure>
<p>In the website’s most recent version, they display a famous line from the work of English poet John Donne, “for whom the bell tolls, it tolls for thee” on the main page. Threat actors also use this line as the string for the mutex in their final payload, the Babuk ransomware.</p>
<figure id="attachment_135652" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-135652" style="width: 900px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-135652" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/07/word-image-827485-135642-4.jpeg" alt="Website for &quot;RA World&quot; with a dark, futuristic interface featuring neon blue and green lines on a grid layout. Heading at the top reads &quot;Welcome to RA World&quot; followed by a smaller caption &quot;For whom the bell tolls, it tolls for thee.&quot; Bottom half of the page displays the phrase &quot;Customers who refuse to pay&quot; underscored by two buttons labeled &quot;PUNISHED&quot; in a stylized font. Some of the information is redacted. " width="900" height="495" srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/07/word-image-827485-135642-4.jpeg 1224w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/07/word-image-827485-135642-4-786x432.jpeg 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/07/word-image-827485-135642-4-768x422.jpeg 768w" sizes="(max-width: 900px) 100vw, 900px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-135652" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 4. RA World’s current leak site main page.</figcaption></figure>
<p>Figure 5 shows the bottom portion of the group’s main page, which contains a link to an X (formerly Twitter) search. The right-hand side of the screenshot claims a “copyright” for the site under their new RA World name, but as of this writing, the X search link still points to the older search term, <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">ragroup</span>.</p>
<figure id="attachment_135654" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-135654" style="width: 790px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-135654" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/07/word-image-830030-135642-5.png" alt="Twitter logo on the left with a clickable URL link to a Twitter account on the right and the text &quot;Copyright © RA World 2023&quot; below." width="790" height="90" srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/07/word-image-830030-135642-5.png 790w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/07/word-image-830030-135642-5-786x90.png 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/07/word-image-830030-135642-5-768x87.png 768w" sizes="(max-width: 790px) 100vw, 790px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-135654" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 5. RA World’s reference to a related X search at the bottom of their leak site.</figcaption></figure>
<p>X is considered a major platform for security vendors and researchers to share findings, so it would make sense for the threat actor to follow use of their name for publications about their activity.</p>
<p>Figure 6 shows a victim’s leak page from early 2024 where RA World attempted to publicly damage the victim’s reputation by stating what they allege is the real “cost per customer.” They arrive at this figure by taking the total requested ransom amount divided by the number of the victim’s customers, if the victim is a customer-facing company. They frame this figure in terms of what the victim is unwilling to pay to “protect their customers’ privacy.”</p>
<figure id="attachment_135656" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-135656" style="width: 900px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-135656" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/07/word-image-832668-135642-6.png" alt="The image is a screenshot of RA World's website titled &quot;RA World&quot;. Highlighted in a red rectangle is a section labeled &quot;Type&quot;, containing the text, &quot;This company isn't willing to pay $0.5 per customer to protect their privacy.&quot; There are additional tabs or sections labeled &quot;Home&quot; and &quot;Victim&quot; visible at the top of the image." width="900" height="187" srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/07/word-image-832668-135642-6.png 1043w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/07/word-image-832668-135642-6-786x164.png 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/07/word-image-832668-135642-6-768x160.png 768w" sizes="(max-width: 900px) 100vw, 900px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-135656" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 6. An example of a victim’s webpage on RA World’s leak site.</figcaption></figure>
<p>The threat actors updated the victim’s leak page in the leak site's recent version, as shown in Figure 7 below. They removed the “cost per customer” figure, but they added a “Coming soon….” section that displays new victims who will soon be listed. This section is most likely meant to include victims who were not willing to pay the ransom, and RA World is still in the process of uploading their exfiltrated data.</p>
<figure id="attachment_135658" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-135658" style="width: 900px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-135658" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/07/word-image-835269-135642-7.png" alt="The image depicts a futuristic-looking webpage titled &quot;RA World&quot; with a &quot;Coming soon...&quot; header. The sharp blue and black color scheme gives a cybernetic feel, with luminous lines and a dark background. It features a form titled &quot;Target Introduction&quot; with fields such as Name, Official Website, Size in GB, Content, Schedule for Document Public Release, Sample File Download Address, and a schedule area marked &quot;To be determined&quot;. The top navigation includes options labeled &quot;Home&quot; and &quot;Victim&quot;. There is no personal or sensitive real information displayed; the form fields are blank." width="900" height="516" srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/07/word-image-835269-135642-7.png 1170w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/07/word-image-835269-135642-7-767x440.png 767w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/07/word-image-835269-135642-7-768x440.png 768w" sizes="(max-width: 900px) 100vw, 900px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-135658" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 7. An example of a victim’s “coming soon” webpage on RA World’s leak site’s recent version.</figcaption></figure>
<h2><a id="post-135642-_6i73jrspy2nk"></a>Technical Analysis</h2>
<p>We have mapped the attack stages using the MITRE ATT&amp;CK framework to activities that are common to RA World.</p>
<h3><a id="post-135642-_209jgeeu40kt"></a>Initial Access</h3>
<p>Based on our telemetry, RA World predominantly exploits misconfigured or vulnerable internet-facing servers. We have not observed instances of phishing attacks to gain initial access to the environment.</p>
<h3><a id="post-135642-_n983oxekgdvh"></a>Credentials Dumping</h3>
<p>We observed the threat actor attempting to use the <a href="https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/sysinternals/downloads/psexec" target="_blank" rel="noopener">PsExec</a> utility to dump credentials by executing another <a href="https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/sysinternals/downloads/sysinternals-suite" target="_blank" rel="noopener">SysInternals</a> tool, <a href="https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/sysinternals/downloads/procdump" target="_blank" rel="noopener">ProcDump</a>. They also attempted to run the <a href="https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows-server/administration/windows-commands/quser" target="_blank" rel="noopener"><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">quser</span></a> and <a href="https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows-server/administration/windows-commands/tscon" target="_blank" rel="noopener"><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">tscon</span></a> commands to retrieve data about the current user and remote session.</p>
<p>Figure 8 below shows Cortex XDR prevented these attempts.</p>
<figure id="attachment_135660" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-135660" style="width: 700px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-135660" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/07/word-image-838672-135642-8.jpeg" alt="Flowchart diagram showing a process with two main branches, connected by various nodes and labels. Below is a navigation bar with multiple icons and text including &quot;SOURCE,&quot; &quot;SEVERITY,&quot; &quot;ACTION&quot; and more. " width="700" height="254" srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/07/word-image-838672-135642-8.jpeg 2048w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/07/word-image-838672-135642-8-786x285.jpeg 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/07/word-image-838672-135642-8-1920x697.jpeg 1920w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/07/word-image-838672-135642-8-768x279.jpeg 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/07/word-image-838672-135642-8-1536x557.jpeg 1536w" sizes="(max-width: 700px) 100vw, 700px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-135660" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 8. A prevented attempt of executing multiple commands as seen in Cortex XDR.</figcaption></figure>
<h3><a id="post-135642-_g62xh6or29td"></a>Lateral Movement</h3>
<p>To move laterally in the compromised network and execute commands on remote endpoints, RA World used the popular <a href="https://github.com/fortra/impacket" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Impacket</a> tool. They executed remote commands to dump the <a href="https://cylab.be/blog/311/explore-the-sam-hive-with-regedit-and-sysinternals" target="_blank" rel="noopener">SAM hive</a>, copied the <a href="https://medium.com/@harikrishnanp006/understanding-ntds-dit-the-core-of-active-directory-faac54cc628a" target="_blank" rel="noopener">NTDS database</a> and exported the system registry.</p>
<p>The threat actor then used the <a href="https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows-server/administration/windows-commands/makecab" target="_blank" rel="noopener"><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">makecab</span></a> utility to archive the databases and deleted the previously extracted database files from disk. Table 1 below shows the commands and their descriptions.</p>
<table style="width: 100%;">
<tbody>
<tr>
<td style="text-align: center; width: 74.7509%;"><b>Command</b></td>
<td style="text-align: center; width: 24.5847%;"><b>Description</b></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 74.7509%;"><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">cmd.exe /Q /c copy \\?\GLOBALROOT\Device\HarddiskVolumeShadowCopy3\windows\NTDS\ntds.dit [redacted].dit 1&gt; \\127.0.0.1\ADMIN$\__1706227818.9154336 2&gt;&amp;1</span></td>
<td style="width: 24.5847%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Copying the NTDS database</span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 74.7509%;"><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">cmd.exe /Q /c copy \\?\GLOBALROOT\Device\HarddiskVolumeShadowCopy3\Windows\System32\config\SAM [redacted].hiv 1&gt; \\127.0.0.1\ADMIN$\__1706227818.9154336 2&gt;&amp;1</span></td>
<td style="width: 24.5847%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Exporting the SAM hive</span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 74.7509%;"><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">cmd.exe /Q /c copy \\?\GLOBALROOT\Device\HarddiskVolumeShadowCopy3\Windows\System32\config\SYSTEM [redacted].hiv 1&gt; \\127.0.0.1\ADMIN$\__1706227818.9154336 2&gt;&amp;1</span></td>
<td style="width: 24.5847%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Exporting the system’s registry</span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 74.7509%;"><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">cmd.exe /Q /c makecab [redacted].dit [redacted].zip 1&gt; \\127.0.0.1\ADMIN$\__1706227818.9154336 2&gt;&amp;1</span></td>
<td style="width: 24.5847%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">An example of archiving the NTDS database</span></td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
<p>Table 1. The RA World’s lateral movement and credentials dumping commands and their respective descriptions.</p>
<p>The attackers executed the above commands under the <a href="https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/wmisdk/wmi-start-page" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Windows Management Instrument</a> (WMI) Provider Host.</p>
<p>Figure 9 shows the alerts raised when Cortex XDR detected them.</p>
<figure id="attachment_135662" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-135662" style="width: 700px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-135662" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/07/word-image-841384-135642-9.jpeg" alt="The image displays a computer security alert interface highlighting a medium severity threat, detected and reported as a suspicious process creation involving &quot;WmiPrvSE.exe&quot;, with the interface showing that this is the first alert out of a total of 26. Some of the identifying information has been redacted. " width="700" height="441" srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/07/word-image-841384-135642-9.jpeg 1080w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/07/word-image-841384-135642-9-699x440.jpeg 699w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/07/word-image-841384-135642-9-768x484.jpeg 768w" sizes="(max-width: 700px) 100vw, 700px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-135662" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 9. An alert of malicious WMI activity as seen in Cortex XDR in detect mode.</figcaption></figure>
<h3><a id="post-135642-_gslgoeni3y7e"></a>Persistence and Impact: A Multi-Stage Ransom Infection Chain</h3>
<p>Germán Fernández, a security researcher from Chile, <a href="https://twitter.com/1ZRR4H/status/1752395949542986052" target="_blank" rel="noopener">tweeted</a> about various artifacts found in a ransomware attack by RA World earlier this year. The artifacts he mentioned include various executable files and scripts.</p>
<p><a href="https://www.trendmicro.com/en_us/research/24/c/multistage-ra-world-ransomware.html" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Trend Micro published the first public report</a> of RA World’s updated tool set in early March 2024. Their analysis of the files revealed several stages, each having its own role in the infection process prior to the delivery of the final ransomware payload.</p>
<h4><a id="post-135642-_6y74i0ajoay7"></a>Stage 1: Loader</h4>
<p>The initial loader, also known as <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">Stage1.exe</span>, has two main roles:</p>
<ul>
<li>Perform a variety of checks including assessing the domain name and looking for a file called <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">Exclude.exe</span>. Judging by its name, this file could contain exclusions such as specific machines and file paths.</li>
<li>Add <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">Stage2.exe</span> to the <a href="https://www.blumira.com/sysvol-enumeration/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">SYSVOL shared path</a> and then execute it.</li>
</ul>
<p>The loaders are usually small files with a maximum size of about 10 KB. Figure 10 below shows most of the loader’s code.</p>
<figure id="attachment_135664" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-135664" style="width: 600px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-135664" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/07/word-image-844163-135642-10.jpeg" alt="The image displays a computer screen showing a text editor with lines of code. The code involves domain controllers, accessing system paths, and executing a command on a Windows machine. Some of the information is redacted. " width="600" height="386" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-135664" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 10. A code snippet from Stage1.exe showing its exclusion of files and information gathering about domain controllers.</figcaption></figure>
<h4><a id="post-135642-_q86bvotf65r6"></a>Stage 2: Enable Safe Mode and Deliver Babuk</h4>
<p>The next stage of the infection chain has two separate operation mechanisms that are dependent on whether or not the system is running in safe mode. <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">Stage3.exe</span> must be run in safe mode so it can evade detection by security solutions that, by default, won’t run in this mode. This file is the final ransomware payload, and a new Babuk variant.</p>
<p>If the system is operating in safe mode, the Babuk binary will be decrypted using Advanced Encryption Standard (AES) and then executed, followed by an attempt to disable safe boot. The AES key and initiation vector are generated based on the victim’s local domain name, which the malware would previously have retrieved in <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">Stage1.exe</span>.</p>
<p>Otherwise, <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">Stage2.exe</span> will write itself as a service to the compromised machine, using the following command:</p>
<ul>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">reg add "HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Control\SafeBoot\Network\MSOfficeRunOncelsls" /t REG_SZ /d Service /f</span></li>
</ul>
<p>Figure 11 shows the execution of <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">Stage2.exe</span> that Cortex XDR detected and prevented.</p>
<figure id="attachment_135666" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-135666" style="width: 700px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-135666" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/07/word-image-846657-135642-11.jpeg" alt="Computer security alert interface showing a high-severity warning labeled as &quot;Prevented (Blocked)&quot; under the Behavioral Threat Protection section. The alert details a malicious process named Stage2.exe attempting to run from the Help folder, and it is the first of two alerts being displayed. Some of the information is redacted. " width="700" height="457" srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/07/word-image-846657-135642-11.jpeg 1070w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/07/word-image-846657-135642-11-674x440.jpeg 674w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/07/word-image-846657-135642-11-768x501.jpeg 768w" sizes="(max-width: 700px) 100vw, 700px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-135666" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 11. A description of a prevention alert.</figcaption></figure>
<h4><a id="post-135642-_96w3mrx8iccb"></a>Stage 3: New Variant of the Babuk Final Payload</h4>
<p>Since its discovery in mid-2023, RA World has used a customized version of the Babuk ransomware, which had its source code leaked in 2021. In its recent activity, RA World has updated their Babuk-based payload with some relatively minor changes. Changes in this variant include:</p>
<ul>
<li>Changing the mutex name from <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">DoYouWantToHaveSexWithCuongDong</span> to <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">For whom the bell tolls, it tolls for thee</span></li>
<li>Changing the ransom note filename from <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">How To Restore Your Files.txt </span>to<span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;"> Data breach warning.txt</span>
<ul>
<li>Modifying the note’s content accordingly</li>
</ul>
</li>
<li>Changing the encrypted file extension to <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">.RAWLD</span> from <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">.GAGUP</span></li>
<li>Stripping down the previous variant’s PDB path</li>
<li>Creating the file <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">C:\Windows\Help\Finish.exe</span> to indicate the encryption process is finished</li>
<li>Adding more filenames, paths, processes and service names to exclude during encryption</li>
</ul>
<p>Figures 12 and 13 show Cortex XDR detecting and preventing the execution of RA World’s Babuk payload.</p>
<figure id="attachment_135668" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-135668" style="width: 900px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-135668" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/07/word-image-849532-135642-12.jpeg" alt="Illustration of a cybersecurity threat detection workflow with three steps: Step 1 displays a computer icon and is labeled &quot;cmd.exe,&quot; indicating a command prompt action. Step 2 shows a shield icon suggesting security software detecting the activity, marked as &quot;Detected (Reported).&quot; The final Step 3 presents a lock icon with a warning sign, indicating high severity, and describes &quot;An unsigned process encrypting files, possible ransomware.&quot; Below, a command line text reads &quot;C:\Windows\System32\cmd.exe /c vssadmin.exe delete shadows /all /quiet.&quot; An alert message states, &quot;Process requests the deletion of Windows shadow copies,&quot; categorized as &quot;Tampering." width="900" height="344" srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/07/word-image-849532-135642-12.jpeg 1758w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/07/word-image-849532-135642-12-786x300.jpeg 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/07/word-image-849532-135642-12-768x293.jpeg 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/07/word-image-849532-135642-12-1536x586.jpeg 1536w" sizes="(max-width: 900px) 100vw, 900px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-135668" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 12. Detection of the Babuk ransomware payload as seen in Cortex XDR in detect mode.</figcaption></figure>
<figure id="attachment_135670" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-135670" style="width: 500px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-135670" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/07/word-image-852077-135642-13.png" alt="Alert window from Cortex XDR stating that a malicious activity was blocked. The application involved is named &quot;Stage3.exe&quot; with an unknown publisher, described as a suspicious executable. Buttons for &quot;Show details&quot; and &quot;OK&quot; are visible, with a message advising to contact the help desk for further information." width="500" height="272" srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/07/word-image-852077-135642-13.png 1062w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/07/word-image-852077-135642-13-786x428.png 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/07/word-image-852077-135642-13-768x418.png 768w" sizes="(max-width: 500px) 100vw, 500px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-135670" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 13. A prevention alert of the Babuk ransomware payload as seen in Cortex XDR in prevent mode.</figcaption></figure>
<h2><a id="post-135642-_o1plkreu5o58"></a>RA World’s TTP Similarities With BRONZE STARLIGHT: A Possible, Yet Unverified, Connection</h2>
<p>During our research, we identified some connections in the forensic data found in our telemetry that, with a low-confidence attribution level, tie RA World with <a href="https://malpedia.caad.fkie.fraunhofer.de/actor/bronze_starlight" target="_blank" rel="noopener">BRONZE STARLIGHT (aka Emperor Dragonfly)</a>. BRONZE STARLIGHT is a Chinese threat group that deploys different ransomware payloads.</p>
<p>Several of the TTPs we found overlapped with TTPs used by BRONZE STARLIGHT, as discussed by <a href="https://www.sygnia.co/threat-reports-and-advisories/revealing-emperor-dragonfly-a-chinese-ransomware-group/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Sygnia</a> in 2022<strong>. </strong></p>
<ul>
<li><strong>NPS tool use:</strong> During our research, we found that the attackers were using <a href="https://github.com/ehang-io/nps" target="_blank" rel="noopener">NPS</a>, an open-source tool created by a Chinese developer. The tool’s latest release was back in 2021, and it’s mainly used by Chinese threat actors. According to Sygnia, BRONZE STARLIGHT previously used this tool.</li>
</ul>
<p>The path that the NPS tool was operating from in this research shares similarities with BRONZE STARLIGHT’s chosen path conventions. Table 2 below presents these similarities.</p>
<p>These folders exist by default in the operating system, so this is not sufficient evidence by itself to connect the related activity to this group or another. However, we believe that it is not coincidental that two ransomware groups use this uncommon tool and choose to place it under a similar path on infected environments, using the <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">update</span> suffix for both files.</p>
<table style="width: 100%;">
<tbody>
<tr>
<td style="text-align: center;"><b>RA World</b></td>
<td style="text-align: center;"><b>BRONZE STARLIGHT</b></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><b><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">C:\Windows\Help\</span></b><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">Windows\ContentStore\[redacted]_</span><b><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">update</span></b><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">.exe</span></td>
<td><b><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">C:\Windows\Help\</span></b><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">mui\0409\Windows</span><b><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">Update</span></b><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">.exe</span></td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
<p>Table 2. File path and naming convention similarities between the NPS tool variants deployed by RA World and BRONZE STARLIGHT.</p>
<ul>
<li><strong>Impacket use:</strong> RA World used the same Impacket modules that Sygnia’s report mentions, to facilitate reconnaissance and lateral movement.</li>
<li><strong>Babuk use:</strong> The latest final ransomware payload of both of the groups is based on Babuk’s <a href="https://socradar.io/mutation-effect-of-babuk-code-leakage-new-ransomware-variants/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">leaked source code</a>.</li>
<li><strong>VirusTotal submitter origin country:</strong> When pivoting through VirusTotal and searching for files containing the string <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">C:\Windows\Help\Exclude.exe</span>, we noticed that the same submitter hailing from Hong Kong uploaded multiple variants of the <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">Stage1.exe</span> loader.</li>
</ul>
<p>Some variants’ code iterations look incomplete, and this strengthens our assumption that this might be the threat actor testing their arsenal for detection rates.</p>
<p>One variant included the two strings seen in Figure 14 below. These strings contained internal IP addresses, which did not exist in other samples. The presence of these strings also indicates that this is an early loader variant likely in a development phase.</p>
<figure id="attachment_135672" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-135672" style="width: 298px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-135672 size-full" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/07/word-image-854687-135642-14.png" alt="Text showing two URLs: &quot;http://127 dot 0 dot 0 dot 1:8888/Stage2 dot exe&quot; and &quot;http://192 dot 168 dot 15 dot 13:8080&quot; on a plain background." width="298" height="47" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-135672" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 14. IP strings from a presumed test variant of RA World’s loader malware.</figcaption></figure>
<p>All the submissions had only one distinct submitter. This submitter uploaded one sample after another with a few minutes in between, on July 3, 2023. Figure 15 below shows the submitter information.</p>
<figure id="attachment_135674" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-135674" style="width: 500px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-135674" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/07/word-image-856885-135642-15.png" alt="Screenshot showing data related to a file, including timestamps and locations. All recorded activities happen in Hong Kong on the same date and time, with the source marked as Stage1.exe and a web origin. There is one submitter and a total of one submission." width="500" height="229" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-135674" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 15. Submitter information from VirusTotal about the unique uploader of the loader files.</figcaption></figure>
<ul>
<li><strong>The threat actor’s operating time zone:</strong> Analyzing our telemetry, we noticed that threat actors executed the vast majority of reconnaissance and lateral movement-related commands on infected devices during office hours of the GMT +7 to GMT +9 time-zones.</li>
<li><strong>Misspellings in the code:</strong> While looking at the code of the different malware, we saw that logs by the author had clear mistakes in their use of English. Although it does not indicate a specific geographical location of an author, combining this finding together with other aforementioned points indicates that the threat developers are likely not native English speakers.Figures 16 and 17 below show examples of misspellings.</li>
</ul>
<figure id="attachment_135676" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-135676" style="width: 305px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-135676" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/07/word-image-859023-135642-16.png" alt="Code snippet in C# showing a conditional statement that prints &quot;Is runing!&quot; and exits the environment if a flag is true. There is a spelling error in the word &quot;running." width="305" height="76" srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/07/word-image-859023-135642-16.png 305w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/07/word-image-859023-135642-16-300x76.png 300w" sizes="(max-width: 305px) 100vw, 305px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-135676" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 16. A first example of a typo in RA World’s code.</figcaption></figure>
<figure id="attachment_135678" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-135678" style="width: 516px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-135678" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/07/word-image-861416-135642-17.png" alt="This image displays a snippet of computer code in a dark-themed text editor. The code is written in C# and is part of an exception handling block that catches exceptions. When an exception occurs, the first line within the catch block logs the message &quot;----Try to restart by SafeMode Failed----&quot; (except that failed is misspelled) to a log file using a method named &quot;SaveLog&quot;. The second line logs the exception details using the same &quot;SaveLog&quot; method. The code features syntax highlighting with keywords in blue, strings in red, and comments in green." width="516" height="80" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-135678" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 17. A second example of a typo in RA World’s code.</figcaption></figure>
<p>However, it is important to note that there could be other explanations for the connections described here. For example, other threat actors might coincidentally use Babuk or some of the same open source tooling, and threat actors from other countries might be prone to the same types of misspellings. Therefore, while the possible ties to BRONZE STARLIGHT bring up intriguing possibilities, we assess the connection with low confidence at this time.</p>
<h2><a id="post-135642-_lb29qdv9ijxk"></a>Conclusion</h2>
<p>In this article, we reviewed the latest developments in the operation of RA World that has recently rebranded itself from RA Group. We described evolutions in both their leak site and their operational tools. They used two different loaders to deliver their final payload, which was a new variant of the Babuk ransomware.</p>
<p>The RA World group remains steadily active, and they primarily affect the manufacturing sector according to their public leak site data.</p>
<h2><a id="post-135642-_b1mrj9e1w0x4"></a>Protections and Mitigations</h2>
<p>Palo Alto Networks customers are better protected from the different TTPs used by RA World.</p>
<p>The <a href="https://docs-cortex.paloaltonetworks.com/p/XDR">Cortex XDR</a> and <a href="https://docs-cortex.paloaltonetworks.com/p/XSIAM" target="_blank" rel="noopener">XSIAM</a> platforms detect and prevent the execution flows described in the screenshots included in the previous sections. <a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/cortex/cortex-xpanse" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Cortex Xpanse</a> is able to provide visibility that can prove valuable for proactive protection.</p>
<p>The Cortex XDR agent included out of the box protections that prevented adverse behavior from the samples we tested from this group, without the need for specific detection logic or signatures.</p>
<p>Cortex XDR and XSIAM detect user- and credential-based threats by analyzing user activity from multiple data sources including the following:</p>
<ul>
<li>Endpoints</li>
<li>Network firewalls</li>
<li>Active Directory</li>
<li>Identity and access management solutions</li>
<li>Cloud workloads</li>
</ul>
<p>Cortex XDR and XSIAM build behavioral profiles of user activity over time with machine learning. By comparing new activity to past activity, peer activity and the expected behavior of the entity, Cortex XDR and XSIAM detect anomalous activity indicative of credential-based attacks.</p>
<p>They are also designed offer the following protections related to the attacks discussed in this post:</p>
<ul>
<li>Preventing the execution of known malicious malware</li>
<li>Preventing execution of unknown malware using <a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/products/secure-the-network/subscriptions/threat-prevention" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Behavioral Threat Prevention</a> and machine learning based on the Local Analysis module</li>
<li>Protecting against credential-gathering tools and techniques using the Credential Gathering Protection, available from Cortex XDR 3.4</li>
<li>Protecting against exploitation of different vulnerabilities including ProxyShell using the Anti-Exploitation modules as well as Behavioral Threat Protection</li>
</ul>
<p>Cortex XDR is designed to detect post-exploitation activity, including credential-based attacks, with <a href="https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/cortex/cortex-xdr/cortex-xdr-analytics-alert-reference/cortex-xdr-analytics-alert-reference/analytics-alerts-by-required-data-source" target="_blank" rel="noopener">behavioral analytics</a>.</p>
<p>The <a href="https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/prisma/prisma-cloud" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Prisma Cloud</a> Defender as well as Cortex XDR for cloud agents should be deployed on cloud-based Windows virtual machines to ensure they are protected from these known malicious binaries. <a href="https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/wildfire" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Advanced WildFire</a> signatures can be used by both Palo Alto Networks cloud services to ensure cloud-based Windows virtual machine runtime operations are being analyzed and those resources are protected.</p>
<p><a href="https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/cdss" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Cloud-Delivered Security Services</a> for the <a href="https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/ngfw" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Next-Generation Firewall</a> such as <a href="https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/wildfire" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Advanced WildFire</a> and <a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/network-security/advanced-url-filtering" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Advanced URL Filtering</a> include protections based on the IoCs shared in this article.</p>
<p>If you think you might have been impacted or have an urgent matter, get in touch with the <a href="https://start.paloaltonetworks.com/contact-unit42.html" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Unit 42 Incident Response team</a> or call:</p>
<ul>
<li>North America Toll-Free: 866.486.4842 (866.4.UNIT42)</li>
<li>EMEA: +31.20.299.3130</li>
<li>APAC: +65.6983.8730</li>
<li>Japan: +81.50.1790.0200</li>
</ul>
<p>Palo Alto Networks has shared these findings with our fellow Cyber Threat Alliance (CTA) members. CTA members use this intelligence to rapidly deploy protections to their customers and to systematically disrupt malicious cyber actors. Learn more about the <a href="https://www.cyberthreatalliance.org" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Cyber Threat Alliance</a>.</p>
<h2><a id="post-135642-_kl40t98ff9o6"></a>Indicators of Compromise</h2>
<h3><a id="post-135642-_joy52hst2fco"></a>Examples of Stage 1</h3>
<ul>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">2a4e83ff1c48baa3d526d51d09782933cec6790d5fa8ccea07633826f378b18a</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">57225f38b58564cf7ec1252fbf12475abee58bd6ea9500eb7570c49f8dc6a64c</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">93aae0d740df62b5fd57ac69d7be75d18d16818e87b70ace5272932aa44f23e4</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">af4a08bbe9f698a8a9666c76c6bdac9a29b7a9572e025f85f2a6f62c293c0f5e</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">f1c576ed08abbb21d546a42a0857a515d617db36d2e4a49bedd9c25034ccd1e2</span></li>
</ul>
<h3><a id="post-135642-_hezb8jrtgaz4"></a>Examples of Stage 2</h3>
<ul>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">2d22cbe3b1d13af824d10bb55b61f350cb958046adf5509768a010df53409aa8</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">330730d65548d621d46ed9db939c434bc54cada516472ebef0a00422a5ed5819</span></li>
</ul>
<h3><a id="post-135642-_g58a34kmopq9"></a>Examples of Stage 3 (Babuk Variant)</h3>
<ul>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">9479a5dc61284ccc3f063ebb38da9f63400d8b25d8bca8d04b1832f02fac24de</span></li>

<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">74fb402bc2d7428a61f1ac03d2fb7c9ff8094129afd2ec0a65ef6a373fd31183</span></li>

<h2><a id="post-135642-_v6mzu0oqzp"></a>Additional References</h2>
<ul>
<li><a href="https://blog.talosintelligence.com/ra-group-ransomware/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Newly identified RA Group compromises companies in U.S. and South Korea with leaked Babuk source code</a> – Talos Intelligence, Cisco</li>
<li><a href="https://www.trendmicro.com/en_us/research/24/c/multistage-ra-world-ransomware.html" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Multistage RA World Ransomware Uses Anti-AV Tactics, Exploits GPO</a> – Trend Micro</li>
<li><a href="https://securityaffairs.com/146248/cyber-crime/new-ra-group.html" target="_blank" rel="noopener">New RA Group ransomware gang is the latest group using leaked Babuk source code</a> – Security Affairs</li>
<li><a href="https://cylab.be/blog/311/explore-the-sam-hive-with-regedit-and-sysinternals" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Explore the SAM hive with Regedit (and Sysinternals)</a> – Cyber Defence Lab of the Royal Military Academy (Belgium)</li>
<li><a href="https://medium.com/@harikrishnanp006/understanding-ntds-dit-the-core-of-active-directory-faac54cc628a" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Understanding NTDS.DIT: The Core of Active Director</a> – Harikrishnan P. on Medium</li>
<li><a href="https://twitter.com/1ZRR4H/status/1752395949542986052" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Germán Fernández @1ZRR4H on X (formerly Twitter)</a></li>
<li><a href="https://www.blumira.com/sysvol-enumeration/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">How To Detect SYSVOL Enumeration Exploits</a> – Blumira</li>
<li><a href="https://malpedia.caad.fkie.fraunhofer.de/actor/bronze_starlight" target="_blank" rel="noopener">BRONZE STARLIGHT (Threat Actor)</a> – Malpedia</li>
<li><a href="https://www.sygnia.co/threat-reports-and-advisories/revealing-emperor-dragonfly-a-chinese-ransomware-group/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Revealing Emperor Dragonfly: Night Sky and Cheerscrypt - A Single Ransomware Group</a> – Sygnia</li>
<li><a href="https://socradar.io/mutation-effect-of-babuk-code-leakage-new-ransomware-variants/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Mutation Effect of Babuk Code Leakage: New Ransomware Variants</a> – SOCRadar</li>
</ul>
<p>&nbsp;</p>

    <div class="l-container">
            <h2>Related Ransomware Resources</h2>
      <div class="blog-slider" id="blogSlider"> 
                    <div class="pa l-card l-card--slider" >
              <div class="card-media " >
                              <figure>
                <img width="718" height="440" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/10/01_Ransomware_Category_1505x922-718x440.jpg" class="attachment-medium size-medium" alt="Pictorial representation of Lynx ransomware. A digital illustration of glowing chains with broken links, set against a background of binary code in blue and red." decoding="async" srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/10/01_Ransomware_Category_1505x922-718x440.jpg 718w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/10/01_Ransomware_Category_1505x922-1143x700.jpg 1143w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/10/01_Ransomware_Category_1505x922-768x470.jpg 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/10/01_Ransomware_Category_1505x922.jpg 1505w" sizes="(max-width: 718px) 100vw, 718px" />                </figure> 
                            </div>
              <div class="card-content">
                <div class="card-content__wrapper">
                  <a class="card-category" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/top-cyberthreats/" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="ra-world-ransomware-group-updates-tool-set:related-resources:Lynx Ransomware: A Rebranding of INC Ransomware:High Profile Threats"><span class=""><img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/07/top-threats.svg" alt=" category icon">High Profile Threats</span></a>                  <a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/inc-ransomware-rebrand-to-lynx/" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="ra-world-ransomware-group-updates-tool-set:related-resources:Lynx Ransomware: A Rebranding of INC Ransomware">
                    <h4 class="post-title">Lynx Ransomware: A Rebranding of INC Ransomware</h4>
                  </a>
                  <ul class="card-tags" role="list">
				<li role="listitem">
					<a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/leak-site/" title="Leak site" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="ra-world-ransomware-group-updates-tool-set:related-resources:Lynx Ransomware: A Rebranding of INC Ransomware:Leak site">Leak site</a>
				</li>
				<li role="listitem">
					<a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/double-extortion/" title="double extortion" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="ra-world-ransomware-group-updates-tool-set:related-resources:Lynx Ransomware: A Rebranding of INC Ransomware:double extortion">Double extortion</a>
				</li></ul>                </div>
                <div class="card-content__link">
                                    <a class="hyperlink" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/inc-ransomware-rebrand-to-lynx/" title="Lynx Ransomware: A Rebranding of INC Ransomware" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="ra-world-ransomware-group-updates-tool-set:related-resources:Lynx Ransomware: A Rebranding of INC Ransomware:read now">
                    Read now                    <img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/icon-right-arrow-withtail.svg" alt="Right arrow">
                  </a>
                </div>
              </div>
            </div>

              <div class="card-media " >
                              <figure>
                <img width="786" height="368" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/06_Ransomware_Category_1920x900-786x368.jpg" class="attachment-medium size-medium" alt="A pictorial representation of Cicada3301 ransomware.             </div>
                                <div class="pa l-card l-card--slider" >
              <div class="card-media " >
                              <figure>
                <img width="786" height="368" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/03_Ransomware_Category_1920x900-786x368.jpg" class="attachment-medium size-medium" alt="A digital illustration of a glowing red padlock symbol superimposed over a detailed circuit board background, emphasizing themes of cybersecurity and data protection. The image features vibrant red and blue lights to highlight the technological context." decoding="async" srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/03_Ransomware_Category_1920x900-786x368.jpg 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/03_Ransomware_Category_1920x900-1493x700.jpg 1493w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/03_Ransomware_Category_1920x900-768x360.jpg 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/03_Ransomware_Category_1920x900-1536x720.jpg 1536w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/03_Ransomware_Category_1920x900.jpg 1920w" sizes="(max-width: 786px) 100vw, 786px" />                </figure> 
                            </div>
              <div class="card-content">
                <div class="card-content__wrapper">
                  <a class="card-category" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/threat-research/" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="ra-world-ransomware-group-updates-tool-set:related-resources:Medusa Ransomware Turning Your Files into Stone:Threat Research"><span class=""><img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/icon-threat-research.svg" alt=" category icon">Threat Research</span></a>                  <a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/medusa-ransomware-escalation-new-leak-site/" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="ra-world-ransomware-group-updates-tool-set:related-resources:Medusa Ransomware Turning Your Files into Stone">
                    <h4 class="post-title">Medusa Ransomware Turning Your Files into Stone</h4>
                  </a>
                  <ul class="card-tags" role="list">
				<li role="listitem">
					<a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/medusa-ransomware/" title="Medusa ransomware" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="ra-world-ransomware-group-updates-tool-set:related-resources:Medusa Ransomware Turning Your Files into Stone:Medusa ransomware">Medusa ransomware</a>
				</li>
				<li role="listitem">
					<a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/raas/" title="RaaS" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="ra-world-ransomware-group-updates-tool-set:related-resources:Medusa Ransomware Turning Your Files into Stone:RaaS">RaaS</a>
				</li>
				<li role="listitem">
					<a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/transforming-scorpius/" title="Transforming Scorpius" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="ra-world-ransomware-group-updates-tool-set:related-resources:Medusa Ransomware Turning Your Files into Stone:Transforming Scorpius">Transforming Scorpius</a>
				</li></ul>                </div>
                <div class="card-content__link">

              </div>
            </div>
                                <div class="pa l-card l-card--slider" >
              <div class="card-media " >
                              <figure>
                <img width="786" height="368" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/04_Ransomware_Category_1920x900-786x368.jpg" class="attachment-medium size-medium" alt="A digital illustration of a laptop with cybersecurity imagery including a padlock hologram, surrounded by stacks of coins and a credit card, emphasizing financial security. The setting is illuminated in blue, pink, and purple tones." decoding="async" srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/04_Ransomware_Category_1920x900-786x368.jpg 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/04_Ransomware_Category_1920x900-1493x700.jpg 1493w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/04_Ransomware_Category_1920x900-768x360.jpg 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/04_Ransomware_Category_1920x900-1536x720.jpg 1536w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/04_Ransomware_Category_1920x900.jpg 1920w" sizes="(max-width: 786px) 100vw, 786px" />                </figure> 
                            </div>
              <div class="card-content">
                <div class="card-content__wrapper">
                  <a class="card-category" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/threat-research/" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="ra-world-ransomware-group-updates-tool-set:related-resources:BlackCat Climbs the Summit With a New Tactic:Threat Research"><span class=""><img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/icon-threat-research.svg" alt=" category icon">Threat Research</span></a>                  <a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/blackcat-ransomware-releases-new-utility-munchkin/" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="ra-world-ransomware-group-updates-tool-set:related-resources:BlackCat Climbs the Summit With a New Tactic">

<!--  Start: Footer subscription form -->
<div class="newsletter">
      <div class="l-container">
        <div class="newsletter__wrapper">
          <div class="image__wrapper"> 
            <picture>
			              	 <source media="(max-width:400px)" srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/newsletter-Image-mobile.webp">
			  			               	 <source media="(max-width:949px)" srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/newsletter-Image-tab.webp">
			  			  			  	<img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/Revitalized_newsletter-Image-desktop-copy-1.webp" alt="Newsletter">
			              </picture>
          </div>
          <div class="content__wrapper"> 
		    							<span class="pre-title"> 
				<img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/palo-alto-logo-small.svg" alt="UNIT 42 Small Logo">
				Get updates from Unit 42			</span>
						           	 <h2>Peace of mind comes from staying ahead of threats. Contact us today.</h2>
			            <form action="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/apps/pan/public/formsubmithandler.submitform.json" method="post" novalidate class="subscribe-form" name="Unit42_Subscribe" id="unit42footerSubscription_form">
              <input type="hidden" name="emailFormMask" value="">
              <input type="hidden" value="1086" name="formid">
              <input type="hidden" value="531-OCS-018" name="munchkinId">
              <input type="hidden" value="2141" name="lpId">
              <input type="hidden" value="1203" name="programId">
              <input type="hidden" value="1086" name="formVid">
              <input type="hidden" name="mkto_optinunit42" value="true">
              <input type="hidden" name="mkto_opt-in" value="true">
              <div class="form-group"> 
                <label for="newsletter-email"  id="newsletter-email-label">Your Email</label>
                <input type="emal" placeholder="Your Email" name="Email"  class="subscribe-field" id="newsletter-email" aria-labelledby="newsletter-email-label">
                <p class="error-mail mb-15 text-danger" style="color: #dc3545"></p>
				<p>Subscribe for email updates to all Unit 42 threat research.<br />By submitting this form, you agree to our <a title="Terms of Use" href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/legal-notices/terms-of-use" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="Get updates from Unit 42:Terms of Use">Terms of Use</a> and acknowledge our <a title="Privacy Statement" href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/legal-notices/privacy" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="Get updates from Unit 42:Privacy Statement">Privacy Statement.</a></p>
                <div class="g-recaptcha" data-expired-callback="captchaExpires" data-callback="captchaComplete" data-sitekey="6Lc5EhgTAAAAAJa-DzE7EeWABasWg4LKv-R3ao6o"></div>
                <p class="error-recaptcha d-none mt-15 text-danger" style="color: #dc3545">Invalid captcha!</p>
                <button class="l-btn is-disabled" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="footer:Get updates from Unit 42:Subscribe" id="unit42footerSubscription_form_button"> 
					Subscribe					<img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/right-arrow.svg" alt="Right Arrow"  class="arrow">
					<img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/icon-loader.svg" alt="loader" class="loader">
			   </button>
				<div class="form-success-message"></div>
              </div>
            </form>
          </div>
        </div>
      </div>
    </div>

<script>

(function($) {
	// Migrated from the unit42-v5 + Modifications
	var subscribeSuccess = false;
	var email = document.getElementById('newsletter-email');
	var subscription_form = document.getElementById('unit42footerSubscription_form');
	var subscription_form_button = document.getElementById('unit42footerSubscription_form_button');
	window.captchaComplete = function() {
		subscribeSuccess = true;
		if ($(mail).val() != '' && isEmail($(mail).val())) {
			$(subscription_form_button).removeClass('is-disabled');
		}
		setTimeout(function() {
			$(email).focus();
			$('.g-recaptcha iframe').attr('tabindex', '-1');
		}, 100)
	}
	window.captchaExpires = function() {
		subscribeSuccess = false;
		$(subscription_form_button).addClass('is-disabled', true);
	} 
	$(subscription_form).submit(function(e) {
		e.preventDefault();
		e.stopImmediatePropagation();
		updateEmailMask();
		var success = true;
		var form = $(this);
		var mail = form.find('input[name="Email"]');
		
		if (mail.val() === '') {
			mail.addClass('has-error');
			showError(1);
			success = false;	
		}  else if (!isEmail(mail.val())){
			showError(2);
			success = false;
		}
		else {
			mail.removeClass('has-error');
			$('.error-mail').addClass('d-none');
		}

		if (!subscribeSuccess) {
			$('.error-recaptcha').removeClass('d-none');
		} else {
			$('.error-recaptcha').addClass('d-none');
		}

		if (success && subscribeSuccess) {
			$.ajax({
				type: 'POST',
				url: form.attr('action'),
				data: form.serialize(),
				beforeSend: function() {
                 form.find('button').addClass('is-loading');
    			},
				success: function(msg) {
					form.find('.form-success-message').html('<p class="success-message">You have been successfully subscribed</p>');
					form.find('button').removeClass('is-loading');
					$(email).val('');
					clearError();
				},
				error: function(jqXHR, textStatus, errorThrown) {
					$(subscription_form_button).addClass('is-disabled', true);
					form.find('button').removeClass('is-loading');
					
				}
			});
		}
		return false;
	});
	function showError(error_type){
		if(error_type == 1) {
			$('.error-mail').text("Please enter the email address.").addClass('error-show');
			$(subscription_form_button).addClass('is-disabled');
		} else if(error_type == 2){
			$('.error-mail').text("Please provide a valid e-mail address.").addClass('error-show');
			$(subscription_form_button).addClass('is-disabled');
		}	
		$(subscription_form_button).removeClass('is-loading');
	}
	function clearError(){
		$('.error-mail').text("").removeClass('error-show');;
		$(subscription_form_button).removeClass('is-loading');
		$(subscription_form_button).removeClass('is-disabled');
	}
	
	$(email).on('input', function (event) { 
		var email = $(this).val();
		if (isEmail(email) ) {			
			clearError();
		} else if(email == ""){
			clearError();
		} else{
			showError(2);			  
		}
    });

	function isEmail(email) {
		var re = /^(([^<>()\[\]\\.,;:\s@"]+(\.[^<>()\[\]\\.,;:\s@"]+)*)|(".+"))@((\[[0-9]{1,3}\.[0-9]{1,3}\.[0-9]{1,3}\.[0-9]{1,3}\])|(([a-zA-Z\-0-9]+\.)+[a-zA-Z]{2,}))$/;
		return re.test(String(email).toLowerCase());
	}
	
	var captcha_loaded = false;
         if(!captcha_loaded){
            // recaptcha on foucs call
            $(document).on('change paste keyup', '#newsletter-email', function () {
               if($('.g-recaptcha').hasClass('d-none')){
                $('.g-recaptcha').removeClass('d-none');
               }
               if(!captcha_loaded ){
                  captcha_loaded  = true;
                  // trigger loading api.js (recaptcha.js) script
                  var head = document.getElementsByTagName('head')[0];
                  var script = document.createElement('script');
                  script.type = 'text/javascript';
                  script.src = 'https://www.google.com/recaptcha/api.js?hl=en_US';
                  head.appendChild(script);
               }
            });
        }
	
	function updateEmailMask() {
		var email = $("#unit42footerSubscription_form input[name='Email']").val();
		if (email && email.trim() != '') {
			var maskedEmail = maskEmailAddress(email);
			$("#unit42footerSubscription_form input[name='emailFormMask']").val(maskedEmail);
		}
	}

	function maskEmailAddress (emailAddress) {
		function mask(str) {
			var strLen = str.length;
			if (strLen > 4) {
				return str.substr(0, 1) + str.substr(1, strLen - 1).replace(/\w/g, '*') + str.substr(-1,1);
			}
			return str.replace(/\w/g, '*');
		}
		return emailAddress.replace(/([\w.]+)@([\w.]+)(\.[\w.]+)/g, function (m, p1, p2, p3) {
			return mask(p1) + '@' + mask(p2) + p3;
		});

		return emailAddress;
	}

}(jQuery));
//# sourceMappingURL=main.js.map
	
</script>
<!--  End: Footer subscription form -->

						</li>

							<a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/sase/next-gen-casb"   role="link" title="Cloud Access Security Broker" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="footer:Products and services:Network Security Platform:CLOUD DELIVERED SECURITY SERVICES:Advanced Threat Prevention:DNS Security:Data Loss Prevention:IoT Security:Next-Generation Firewalls:Hardware Firewalls:Strata Cloud Manager:SECURE ACCESS SERVICE EDGE:Prisma Access:Prisma SD-WAN:Autonomous Digital Experience Management:Cloud Access Security Broker">Cloud Access Security Broker</a>
						</li>    
																	<li class="footer-menu-nav__item ">

          <button class="modal__play-btn is-minimized is-paused" id="playPauseBtn">

          </button>
          <button class="modal__minimize-btn is-minimized">
            <img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/icon-minimize.svg" alt="Minimize">
          </button>
          <button class="modal__close"> 
            <img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/close-modal.svg" alt="Close button">
          </button>
          <video class="modal__video" id="customVideo">
            <source src="" type="video/mp4">Your browser does not support the video tag.
          </video>
          <div class="modal__post-details" tabindex="-1">       
              <h3>Default Heading</h3>
              <a class="l-btn" href="#" title="Right Arrow Icon" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="overview:explore reports:View all reports">Read the article
              <img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/right-arrow.svg" alt="Right Arrow">
              </a>
          </div>
          <div class="modal__video-controls">
            <div class="modal__video-seekbar input__wrapper"><span></span>
              <label class="is-hidden" for="modalSeekBar">Seekbar</label>
              <input class="custom-range" id="modalSeekBar" type="range" min="0" max="100" value="1">
              <p class="modal__remaining-time"></p>
            </div>
            <button class="modal__play-btn is-paused" id="playPauseBtn">
            <img class="play" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/player-play-icon.svg" alt="Play">
            <img class="pause" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/player-pause-icon1.svg" alt="Pause">
          </button>
            <div class="modal__volume-controls">
              <div class="modal__volume__wrapper">
                <button tabindex="0">
                  <img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/icon-volume.svg" alt="Volume">
                </button>
                <div class="modal__volume-seekbar"><span></span>
                  <label class="is-hidden" for="volumeBar">Volume</label>
                  <input class="volume__bar" id="volumeBar" type="range" min="0" max="1" step="0.1" value="0.7">
                </div>
              </div>
              <button class="modal__minimize-btn" id="minimizeBtn">
                <img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/icon-minimize.svg" alt="Minimize">
              </button>
            </div>
          </div>
        </div>
      </div><!--  End: video modal -->

    <script type="text/javascript">
	var isProcessing = false; 
    function alter_ul_post_values(obj,post_id,ul_type){
	
		if (isProcessing)    
		return;  
		isProcessing = true;   
		var like_nonce = jQuery('#_wpnonce').val();
		jQuery(obj).find("span").html("..");
                jQuery.ajax({
                    type: "POST",
                    url: "https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/plugins/like-dislike-counter-for-posts-pages-and-comments/ajax_counter.php",
                    data: "post_id="+post_id+"&up_type="+ul_type+"&ul_nonce="+like_nonce,
                    success: function(msg){
                            jQuery(obj).find("span").html(msg);
                            isProcessing = false; 
                            jQuery(obj).find('svg').children('path').attr('stroke','#0050FF');
                            jQuery(obj).removeClass('idc_ul_cont_not_liked idc_ul_cont_not_liked_inner');
                    }
 		});
	}
	</script>
    <link rel='stylesheet' id='wpdevart_lightbox_front_end_css-css' href='https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/plugins/lightbox-popup/includes/style/wpdevart_lightbox_front.css?ver=6.6.1' media='all' />
<script src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/js/script.js?ver=1.0.0" id="unit42-v6-navigation-js"></script>

<!--  Start: Scripts Migrated From Unit42-v5 -->
<script type="text/javascript">
const observer_lozad = lozad('.lozad, .lozad-background'); // lazy loads elements with default selector as '.lozad'
observer_lozad.observe();

window.PAN_Clean_Util = {
        isIE: false
};

(function () {
   // INP Util Fix
    function yieldToMain(ms) {
        return new Promise(resolve => setTimeout(resolve, ms));
    }
   window.PAN_Clean_Util.yieldToMain = yieldToMain
})();

if(referer == "Prisma" || referer == "Cortex" || referer == "Sase" || referer == "Unit" || referer == "Ngfw"){
  var Coveo_organizationId = "paloaltonetworksintranet";        
  var techDocsPagePath = "https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/search.html#hd=All%20Prisma%20Cloud%20Documentation&hq=%40panproductcategory%3D%3D(%22Prisma%20Cloud%22)&sort=relevancy&layout=card&numberOfResults=25";
  var languageFromPath="en_US";
  window.Granite = window.Granite || {};
  Granite.I18n = (function() {
  var self = {};
  self.setLocale = function(locale) { };
  self.get = function(text, snippets, note) {
    var out = "";
    if(text){
      if(text ==="coveo.clear"){
        out = "Clear";
      }else if(text ==="coveo.noresultsfound"){
        out = "No results found for this search term.";
      }
    }
    return out;
  };
  return self
  }());
}

  var main_site_critical_top = maindomain_lang+'/etc.clientlibs/panClean/components/mainNavigationComp/clientlibs/panClean/criticalTop.min.js';
  var main_site_defered = maindomain_lang+'/etc.clientlibs/panClean/components/mainNavigationComp/clientlibs/panClean/defered.min.js';
  var main_site_criticalTopBase = maindomain_lang+'/etc.clientlibs/panClean/components/mainNavigationComp/clientlibs/panClean/criticalTopBase.min.js';
  var main_site_criticalTopProductNav = maindomain_lang+'/etc.clientlibs/panClean/components/mainNavigationComp/clientlibs/panClean/criticalTopProductNav.min.js';
window.PAN_MainNavAsyncUrl = maindomain_lang+"/_jcr_content/globals/cleanHeaderPrisma.prismaRenderer.html";

function loadScript(url, defer){
    var script1 = document.createElement('script');
    script1.setAttribute('type', 'text/javascript');
    script1.setAttribute('src',url);
    if(defer == true){
        script1.setAttribute('defer','defer');
    }
    document.head.appendChild(script1);
}
function loadScript1(url, callback){

    var script = document.createElement("script")
    script.type = "text/javascript";
    if (script.readyState){  //IE
        script.onreadystatechange = function(){
            if (script.readyState == "loaded" || script.readyState == "complete"){
                script.onreadystatechange = null;
                callback();
            }
        };
    } else {  //Others
        script.onload = function(){
            callback();
        };
    }
    script.src = url;
    document.getElementsByTagName("head")[0].appendChild(script);
}
if(referer == "Prisma" || referer == "Cortex" || referer == "Sase" || referer == "Unit" || referer == "Ngfw"){
	if(referer == "Unit"){
    setTimeout(function(){
      loadScript(main_site_criticalTopBase, false);
      loadScript1(main_site_criticalTopProductNav, function(){
        window.PAN_initializeProduct2021Nav();
      });
      loadScript(main_site_defered, false);
    }, 3000);
	}
	else{
    setTimeout(function(){
      loadScript1(main_site_critical_top, function(){
        window.PAN_initializeProduct2021Nav();
      });
      loadScript(main_site_defered, false);
    }, 3000);
	}
}

$(document).ready(function () {
    setTimeout(function(){
      $('.article-banner .ab__options ul li a').each(function(){
          	$(this).attr('target', "_blank");
      });
    }, 4000);
});
</script>
